Message.Title: Mark Zuckerberg has a problem
Message.Msg: "Mark Zuckerberg has a problem. He does not seem concerned about monetizating his creation, only interested in enhancing the Facebook user experience. However, shareholders like their companies to make money. Facebook would need to compile more robust data on members to entice advertisers. To do that, it would have to require more information in a member's profile that could perhaps border on privacy invasion or scare members already afraid of identity theft. Two years ago Zuckerberg pushed the social network envelope with "Groups," allowing users to put friends in categories without prior approval of the friend. Clicking to dial a local business through Facebook's Bing should further line Local Corps's pockets because it owns the highly specific Enhanced Directory Assistance patents." Source: Seeking Alpha - A Very Importan Article (My advice: Go to Seeking Alpha and read the complete article at once.)

He doesn't really touch on earnings, only mentions that it should be compared to AOL and whining that it isn't. That's like me asking are you getting a 200ft. yacht or 220ft when you haven't made your first billion yet. Yes, that is some HUGE concern if she doesn't have a strategy to fix search, display and mobile. Bartz didn't have a strategy for 3yrs and we all know how that turned out. Perhaps he is right that Yahoo is sandbagging a little cause it'd be sad to guide down for the year when global online advertising is to grow 15.1%

Message.Title: Yahoo Can't Fix XSS Exploit
Message.Msg: The delusional Yahoo bulls must not be aware that the XSS exploit that Yahoo said was patched on January 9, is once again running wild. Several computer scientists claimed that the vulnerability was not patched. Yahoo's Director of Security claimed it was easy to patch. If Yahoo cant get this under control, and they don't appear able to, many mail users will switch to other services. This company is in crises and wont admit it.

Message.Title: The Bear Case on Yahoo
Message.Msg: The problem at Yahoo starts with the board of directors, which has appointed 5 CEO's in six years. This indicates that board members are not unified on the direction they want the company to go. Appointing new CEO's get some sizzle and interest, but only cash flow sustains a share price. And, as I read this board, the bulls seem to be arguing broadly among themselves. Divesting non-strategic profitable units is all well and good, but how is that capital going to be deployed? This is a big and complex question, but when I buy Valero or JnJ or Google or Adobe....I get a company that KNOWS where it is going. Yahoo seems to have a rather rich valuation for a company which does not have a committed and tested strategic way forward. Just my thoughts...

Topic.Title: Would Microsoft let Apple buy Yahoo?

Message.Msg: I haven't changed my tune on Marissa but its a long ways from the "minors" or lower end Fortune 500 companies to the largest company on the planet. It'd be like Aubrey McClendon going from his Chesapeake to running Exxon or that CEO Johnson of JC. Penney suddenly running Wal-Mart or Zara's...its a HUGE leap! Her positions at Google were all product specific whether maps/search/Google webpage but it was never everything all together. VP of ITunes would make sense IMO. She still hasn't turned Yahoo around and suddenly Coldone ID's are anointing her the next CEO, with Cook in a nursing home and buyout riches. That is funny! If she turns Yahoo around then perhaps she could move onto a division at Apple but unless they make horrible mis-steps I think she's a decade away from such a position.

Topic.Title: The Yahoo Buyout List is Here! Buyout Will occur From Tomorrow until April 29, 2013

Message.Msg: not only a small list but same one for many years! i have a stock ( one of the top life ins. cos.) & they have been rumored to be bought out for 35 yrs. & i hope it never happens! 25 out of 25 times i made money on it! m.m. should of kept her mouth shut at this early stage! she gave signals that nobody should expect any revenue increase for 2013 ( nice to hear) which lowered the positives to asset sales,buy out or buy backs! i question also what part of the money (set aside) previously for actual buybacks aren't being used for companies acquired & for the high cost for her special employees hired! i have MANY cos. with buy backs & their figures are very close when figuring out the diff. from 2011 to 2012 (when considering the shares bought during 2012) but i don't come up with yahoo figures.

Message.Msg: They are coming; there is no doubt about it. Time will tell but the longer the wait, more money for YHOO coffers and shareholders.

Message.Msg: why are you spoiling my accumulation? don't announce it to the world. It is obvious that someone wants Yahoo at below 20. Yahoo made progress and Yahoo Japan did great and Alibaba is on the verge of IPO... lol.. and yahoo led the internet stock down today. smell something funny?

Message.Title: why does Wall Street hate this company?
Message.Msg: even with the recent run up in price, the stock has a very low P/E of around 6, when compared to its peers, oodles of cash on its balance sheet & zero debt. Not to mention improving fundamentals across its entire platform. I just don't get this low valuation?

Topic.Title: GREAT ARTICLE

Message.Msg: In the article, Jackson offers the thesis that Marissa is 'sandbagging' the numbers for 2013. Really??? That's the investment thesis. Maybe Marissa doesn't have any idea what the numbers will be, just like her predecessors.

Topic.Title: why does Wall Street hate this company?

Message.Msg: Its PE isn't 6 btw. unless you're expecting them to unload another $7B of an Asian asset. It made $1.17, for the year, which means its PE is 16.7. IDK, what the peers are off-hand as both Google and Apple were low-to-mid teens last I checked. Yes, it has oodles of cash but the return on that money is less than 1% interest and needs to invest it in companies that will grow revenue. The brings us to the next portion "improving fundamentals"...not really as you could look at Q4 2011 and Q4 2012 and not tell the difference. Their revenue shouldn't have been 2% growth for the 2nd year in-a-row when online advertising is growing double digits. Display ads are in trouble down 11%, if I remember right. Operating income fell 22% from $220M to $190M. Here are the positives: They got more search money charging higher prices and their investment income went from $450M, last year, to $676M this year. I'm not aware of a solid strategy nor huge gamechanging products on the horizon. If so tell me as I didn't listen to the conference call. For Yahoo, to go all "momo" you need huge growth its why barely profitable stocks like Amazon, ISRG, and Priceline have gone to the moon. Yahoo also doesn't dominate in anything anymore requiring a leaders premium. Its kind've a weird company in that it won the lottery, has a vault worth of cash but is so scared to lose it that they sit on it instead of improving the vault so to speak even though it has countless tourists visit it everyday. Where is the merchandising and trinket selling?lol

Topic.Title: YJ deal & Alibaba IPO still catalyst to $25+

Message.Msg: YJ management knows that YHOO got the upper hand if they decided to make a deal with YHOO Ken Goldman. While Alibaba making the announcement that Jack Ma is stepping down as CEO in May this year, again telling the market, IPO is forthcoming and the new CEO will do all the paperworks and IPO roadshows while Ma can concentrate to Alibaba business plans. My take we will see YHOO at $25+ this year.

Topic.Title: I am a buyer of yahoo at these prices---Up from here

Message.Msg: I would not be so sure. MMs are in control, they sold at high 20's and are bringing it down to a desirable level to buy again. They bought in the upper 15's, so I'm guess that it could go all the way down to 16 plus.

Topic.Title: why does Wall Street hate this company?

Message.Msg: "WALL STREET" is NOT a person. It doesn't love or hate anything. What you see is the collective opinion of ALL investors everywhere. That opinion suggests,, based on the last four years, a badly managed company, weak product lines, no vision , a board with an inflated value of the company, no potential buyers at an acceptable price, and a questionable future. The "low" valuation is justified.
